clinical_study.brief_title: Latinos' Beliefs and Communication About Advance Care Planning
clinical_study.official_title: Culturally Competent Communication Intervention to Improve Latinos' Engagement in Advance Care Planning

lead_sponsor.agency: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

clinical_study.source: Weill Medical College of Cornell University

brief_summary.textblock: The proposed research has significant public health relevance and is consistent with the broader goals of public health focuses on improving communication regarding end-of-life care. The development of a Culturally Competent Communication Intervention designed to coach Latino advanced cancer patients in how to communicate EOL goals of care in order to improve their engagement in advance care planning will help reduce Latino/non-Latino disparities in advance care planning and potentially end-of-life care. If the Culturally Competent Communication Intervention proves to be potentially efficacious, there is a strong argument for testing this intervention in a larger, multi-site study to test for effectiveness.

detailed_description.textblock: Compared to whites, Latinos are much less likely to engage in various forms of advance care planning (ACP), including completing advance directives and having end-of-life (EOL) discussions. ACP is critical to provision of quality EOL care, as it has been associated with greater likelihood of patients' EOL wishes being followed. Latino advanced cancer patients are also significantly more likely than their white counterparts to receive futile and burdensome aggressive care at the end-of-life, to die in the ICU, and to have care that runs counter to their preferences and values. Dr. Shen's pilot work, along with the current literature, suggests that targeting ACP may help improve Latinos' EOL care. As such, the proposed project will develop and pilot-test a culturally competent communication (CCC) intervention. First, the CCC intervention will be developed based on results from a questionnaire embedded into a current R01 (MPIs: Prigerson, Maciejewski) assessing Latinos' cultural, familial, and religious beliefs as well as their knowledge, motivation (readiness), and action to engage in ACP. Next, the developed CCC intervention will be vetted among Latino stakeholders and field-tested among Latino advanced cancer patients to guide the finalization of the intervention. Finally, a pilot randomized trial will examine the feasibility, acceptability, and potential efficacy of the CCC intervention at improving engagement in ACP. Results will provide timely insight into a potentially effective, low burden intervention designed to improve Latinos' engagement in ACP.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in knowledge of advance care planning
primary_outcome.description: Knowledge subscale of the Advance Care Planning Engagement survey, which is a 49-item scale with high reliability (Cronbach's alpha = .94). Subscale is 6 items with Likest-type answers ranging from 1=not at all to 5=extremely. Total scores range from 6 (low) to 30 (high).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in readiness/motivation to engage in advance care planning
primary_outcome.description: Readiness/motivation subscale of the Advance Care Planning Engagement survey, which is a 49-item scale with high reliability (Cronbach's alpha = .94). Subscale is 6 items with Likest-type answers ranging from 1=not at all to 5=extremely. Total scores range from 6 (low) to 30 (high).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in self-efficacy to engage in advance care planning
primary_outcome.description: Self-efficacy subscale of the Advance Care Planning Engagement survey, which is a 49-item scale with high reliability (Cronbach's alpha = .94). Subscale is 10 items with Likest-type answers ranging from 1=not at all to 5=extremely. Total scores range from 10 (low) to 50 (high).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in engagement in advance care planning (end-of-life care discussions)
primary_outcome.description: End-of-life care discussions will be measured by asking patients to self-report whether they have discussed any of the following: (1) wishes they have about the care they would like to receive if they were dying and/or (2) advance care directives, with an oncology provider or family member: DNR orders, living wills, durable powers of attorney for health care, assignments of health care proxies (yes/no format). Engagement will be measured as a count to the degree to which they engaged in each of these, with no=0 and yes=1. Total score can range from 0 (low or none) to 10 (high or discussed all domains with providers and family).

primary_outcome.measure: Change in completion of advance directives
primary_outcome.description: completion of advance directives will be assessed by examining the medical chart for completed advance directive documents (DNR order, living will, durable power of attorney, health care proxy). Completion will be measured as a count to the degree to which they completed each of these, with no=0 and yes=1. Scores can range from 0 (low or none completed) to 4 (high or all completed).

arm_group.description: PLAN is a manualized three session intervention designed to improve engagement in advance care planning. It consists of five modules, covering the following for advance care planning: (1) checking awareness of core concepts; (2) clarifying misconceptions; (3) knowledge transferring; (4) goal setting; and (5) rehearsal or communication of advance care planning to loved ones and doctors. All sessions are delivered by a trained and licensed social worker. Patients also receive a 47-page manual to guide them through the intervention.

intervention.intervention_name: Planning for Your Advance Care Needs (PLAN)
intervention.description: PLAN is a manualized intervention that helps patients learn about, plan for, and communicate their advance care plans to their loved ones and doctors. It consists of five modules delivered across three sessions with a trained and licensed social worker: (1) checking awareness; (2) clarifying; (3) knowledge transferring; (4) goal setting; and (5) rehearsing.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Identifying ethnically as Latino
- Locally advanced or metastatic cancer (pancreaticobiliary, esophagogastric, hepatocellular carcinoma, lung, or gynecological cancer) AND have experienced disease progression on at least first-line chemotherapy
- Ability to provide informed consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Not fluent in English or Spanish
- Severely cognitively impaired (as measured by Short Portable Mental Status Questionnaire scores of < 6)
- Too ill or weak to complete the interviews (as judged by interviewer)
- Currently receiving palliative care/hospice at the time of enrollment (to allow prediction of ACP)
- Children and young adults under age 21
- Patients deemed inappropriate for the study by their treating oncologist
